channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Company Says It Never Planned a ‘Thugs for Hire’ App
item.description: Rather than create an “Uber for Assault,” the business said it had intended to create a concierge service, much like the apps allowing users to negotiate for services.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Boy Held on Terrorism Charges
item.description: A 14-year-old British boy has been charged with encouraging and inciting terrorist attacks in Australia.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Poland: F.B.I. Director Regrets Remarks
item.description: The director of the F.B.I., James B. Comey, told the Polish ambassador to the United States that he regretted recent remarks that Polish officials had said amounted to an accusation of complicity in the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: French Investigators Seek Possible Accomplices in Plot to Attack Church
item.description: An Algerian man was arrested Sunday on suspicion of planning the assault, but Prime Minister Manuel Valls said, “This kind of individual does not act alone.”
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Raymond Truy/Mairie De Caudry, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Aurélie Châtelain was found dead in her parked car in Villejuif, France, on Sunday.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Chechen Leader Issues Warning
item.description: Ramzan Kadyrov has told his security forces to fire on Russian federal troops if they try to operate in the region without his approval.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: U.S. Pares Business Blacklist
item.description: The United States Treasury on Thursday removed a Burmese businessman from a blacklist that had barred him from doing business in the United States.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: Volcano Spews Dangerous Ash
item.description: Twin eruptions from the Calbuco volcano in southern Chile have sent vast clouds of ash into the sky, causing concern.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Drone Strikes Reveal Uncomfortable Truth: U.S. Is Often Unsure About Who Will Die
item.description: By most accounts, hundreds of militants have been killed by drones. But when the cloak of secrecy has occasionally been breached, the results of some strikes have turned out to be deeply troubling.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: A predator drone in Afghanistan in 2010.

item.title: Biden Strikes a Softer Tone at Israel Independence Event
item.description: Mr. Biden’s remarks came as the Obama administration works to smooth tensions with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: First Evidence of a Blunder in Drone Strike: 2 Extra Bodies
item.description: When six bodies instead of four were taken from the wreckage after a C.I.A. drone strike in Pakistan and hastily buried, it was a clear signal that the spy agency had made a deadly mistake.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Mike Redwood, via European Pressphoto Agency

item.title: Obama Apologizes After Drone Kills American and Italian Held by Al Qaeda
item.description: A signature antiterrorism policy to be reviewed in addition to how intelligence forces could not have known about the presence of hostages.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Warren Weinstein, an American held hostage by Al Qaeda since 2011, was killed in an American counterterrorism operation.

item.title: Pentagon Announces New Strategy for Cyberwarfare
item.description: The policy marks the fourth time in four months that the Obama administration has named suspected hackers or announced new strategies designed to raise the cost of cyberattacks.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Adam Gadahn Was Propagandist for Al Qaeda Who Sold Terror in English
item.description: Mr. Gadahn was not an operational leader in Al Qaeda, but instead conveyed the group’s message to English-speaking audiences around the globe.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Cuba Moves Closer to Exit U.S. Terror List
item.description: A Republican who had threatened to lead opposition to President Obama’s decision to remove Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism said Thursday that there was no legal mechanism to do so.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Armenian Groups Are Increasingly Focused on Reparations for Genocide
item.description: The Turkish government’s denials of the Armenian genocide is seen by historians and others as an attempt to head off reparation claims by survivors and their descendants.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Fighting Prompts an Exodus From Yemen, Often on Boats
item.description: More than 150,000 people have been forced to flee to other cities or into the countryside, while others have crossed the borders to Saudi Arabia or Oman.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Indian Authorities Put Restrictions on Ford Foundation
item.description: The charity was added to the list of groups that may not give money to Indian organizations without government permission in the wake of complaints about a trust founder’s being accused of embezzling funds.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Europe’s Promised Action on Migration Crisis Is Criticized as Inadequate
item.description: Experts said that the plans were far too small in scale and that they would not do enough to stem the flow of migrants or prevent disasters like a capsizing off Libya.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Alessandro Di Meo/ANSA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Italian Coast Guard rescued dozens of migrants crowded onto an inflatable dinghy on Wednesday off the coast of Libya.

item.title: U.S. Weighs Training Iraqis to Call in American Airstrikes in ISIS Fight
item.description: The idea would be to accelerate aerial attacks, which the Iraqis say are taking too long.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Mazar-i-Sharif Journal: Niche Trade in Lamb Pelts Proves Vital to Ailing Afghan Economy
item.description: Last year, Finland imported nearly a half-million Afghan lamb pelts, auctioning them off to be turned into luxurious women’s coats, among other items.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sayed Mohammad Sultani, left, the largest Afghan fur exporter, examines lamb pelts brought to him by middle men who procure them from shepherds. The pelts are sorted into piles based on quality.
